content: CHAPTER 1504 - NATIONAL AMERICAN INDIAN VETERANS, INCORPORATED: This section recognizes National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated as a corporation and grants them a federal charter under Part B of subtitle II of title 36, United States Code. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is a federally chartered nonprofit corporation in the United States. It has specific purposes, a board of directors, officers, and various powers and restrictions outlined in the relevant sections of the code. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated (referred to as the `corporation'), is a federally chartered nonprofit corporation with specific purposes outlined in its articles of incorporation, constitution, and bylaws. These purposes include upholding and defending the Constitution of the United States while advocating for American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans who served in the Armed Forces. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is a federally chartered nonprofit corporation with specific purposes outlined in its articles of incorporation, constitution, and bylaws. These purposes include promoting social welfare and advocating for the needs of American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans, their families, or survivors in dealings with government agencies. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is a federally chartered nonprofit corporation with specific purposes outlined in its articles of incorporation, constitution, and bylaws. These purposes include promoting social welfare and advocating for the needs of American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans, their families, or survivors in dealings with state government agencies. The organization also conducts nonpartisan research on the relationship between these veterans and American society, and provides technical assistance to regional areas without veterans committees or organizations. Membership eligibility, board of directors responsibilities, and officer elections are determined by the corporation's constitution and bylaws. The corporation's membership, board of directors, and officer elections are governed by its constitution, bylaws, and the laws of the jurisdiction where it is incorporated. Nondiscrimination is mandated in membership and leadership roles based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin, handicap, or age. The corporation's powers are limited to those granted in its articles of incorporation and constitution. The corporation has exclusive rights to use specific names, seals, emblems, and badges. There are restrictions on stock and dividends. The corporation is restricted from issuing stock or paying dividends. Income or assets cannot benefit members, officers, or directors during the charter's lifespan, except for approved compensation and expenses. The corporation is prohibited from making loans to its officers, directors, members, or employees. It cannot claim congressional approval or federal authority for its activities. It must maintain its tax-exempt status and keep records for inspection. The corporation must keep accurate records of accounts, meeting minutes, and member information at its principal office. These records can be inspected by members with voting rights or their representatives for valid reasons at any reasonable time. These records can be inspected by members or their representatives for any proper purpose at any reasonable time. The corporation shall comply with the laws of the jurisdiction under which it is incorporated and where it carries out its activities for service of process within the United States and its territories. The corporation is liable for the acts of its officers and agents when they act within their authority. Failure to comply with the chapter's restrictions will result in the expiration of the charter. The corporation must report annually to Congress on its activities. The corporation must report annually to Congress on its activities, with the report not being a public document. The report should be submitted along with the audit report required by section 10101(b) of this title. "National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is required to report annually to Congress on its activities."
